user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

This is an example of discharge summary letter:
Dear ___,

You came into hospital because you were getting more short of breath and your ankles were swollen.

A heart scan, called an echocardiogram, showed that your heart was not pumping as well as it should.

We started you on water tablets called Furosemide. They will stop fluid collecting in your legs and lungs.

Please take 2 Furosemide tablets (2 x 40 mg = 80 mg) each morning and weigh yourself each morning.

If your weight drops by more than 2 kg over the week, reduce the dose to 1 tablet per day.

We have asked your GP practice to see you in about 2 weeks' time. They will take a blood test to check your kidney function.

We will see you in 6 weeks' time in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.

You will receive an appointment letter in the post.

Sincerely,
____

Dear ___,

You were admitted to the hospital on March 1, 2024, with severe chest pain radiating to your left arm and shortness of breath. Upon evaluation, an ECG confirmed a diagnosis of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), specifically an acute transmural myocardial infarction of the anterior wall. Immediate intervention included a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement, which stabilized your condition.

During your hospital stay, we closely monitored your progress. By March 2, 2024, you reported feeling better, and a decrease in troponin levels indicated improvement. Over the following days, your vitals remained stable, and there were no further episodes of chest pain. Significant improvement was noted in your condition by March 3, 2024, which allowed us to begin discharge planning and rehabilitation discussion.

Your laboratory tests initially showed elevated troponin peaking 12 hours post-admission, with subsequent decreases, indicating a favorable response to treatment. A complete blood count remained within normal limits, although your lipid profile did reveal elevated LDL cholesterol, which we addressed with medication.

Your treatment plan during hospitalization included Aspirin 325 mg and Clopidogrel 75 mg daily, an IV Heparin infusion, Nitroglycerin as needed for chest pain, Metoprolol 50 mg twice daily, Lisinopril 10 mg daily, and a Statin 40 mg daily. These medications have been prescribed for ongoing management.

At discharge on March 6, 2024, your condition is stable, with no further chest pain and steadily improving cardiac biomarkers. We recommend a follow-up appointment at the cardiology outpatient clinic on March 20, 2024, to assess your recovery and continue medication management.

We strongly encourage adopting lifestyle modifications, including following a heart-healthy diet low in saturated fats, cholesterol, and sodium, with an increased intake of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. Gradually reintroducing physical activity, starting with light walking, is advised, aiming for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity per week. Immediate smoking cessation is essential, and options for nicotine replacement therapy and counseling are recommended. Additionally, exploring stress management techniques, such as mindfulness, yoga, or meditation, may be beneficial.

Please feel free to reach out if you have any questions or concerns. We look forward to supporting you on your road to recovery.

Sincerely,  
___
